keywords.indexterm: Load-balanced server setup for Web Author

body.p: To scale a deployment to a larger number of users and to increase the availability, can be deployed on a set of load-balanced servers. This topic describes the required setup for such a scenario.
body.note: The concurrent editingconcurrent editing feature does not work if is deployed on multiple servers behind a load balancer.

section.title: Configure Session Stickiness
section.p: Every server keeps the state of the edited documents in memory for performance reasons. This implies that every user should connect to the same back-end server for the duration of an editing session. To achieve this result in a load-balanced setting, you should enable session stickiness.By default, Web Author does the JSESSIONID cookie to track the active sessions. Some load-balancers that implement session stickiness by modifying the JSESSIONID session cookie which might break the WebAuthor's session tracking mechanism. In this case, you can change the name of the cookie used to track the session in WEB-INF/shiro.ini configuration file :sessionManager.sessionIdCookie.name = NAME

section.title: Configure Server Health Checks
section.p: To detect unhealthy servers, offers a health check REST API. The endpoint has the following interface:

dlentry.dd: 200 for a healthy server and 503 for an unhealthy server.
For an unhealthy server, the response body contains a text description of the problem.

section.title: Configure the License Server
section.p: All servers can use the same pool of floating licenses. To this end, they all need to be configured to use the same license server.

section.title: Share Configuration Between All Instances
section.p: The configuration (including options, frameworks, and plugins) is stored in the file system in a directory that can be changed using the oxygen.data.dir system property. For all instances to use the same options, oxygen.data.dir should point to the same directory on a shared file system (for example, NFS).
To manage the configuration, you have two options:

ul.li: Use the Administration Page of one of the instances to change these options and then restart all other instances so that they pick up the new configuration.

Create a custom Web Application Archive (WAR) that contains and all the configuration. Every time you want to change the configuration, create a new version of the WAR file and deploy it again. Such a custom WAR can be built using the Web Author Component integration project.
